bibl.title: Roman Foodprints at Berenike. Archaeobotanical Evidence of Subsistence and Trade in the Eastern Desert of Egypt.

series.title: University of California. Cotsen Institute of Archaeology. Monograph

bibl.note: Joint expedition of the University of Delaware and Leiden University, 1994-2001. - Introduction. - 1. Rome's Eastern Trade. - 2. Natural Vegetation. - 3. Living in the Desert. - 4. Archaeobotanical Research. - 5. Peaches in the Desert. - 6. Interpretative Summary and Conclusion. - 7. Catalogue of Taxa. - Bibliography. Index to Scientific Plant Names. General Index.
bibl.seg: CAPPERS René T.J., Roman Foodprints at Berenike. Archaeobotanical Evidence of Subsistence and Trade in the Eastern Desert of Egypt. (University of California. Cotsen Institute of Archaeology. Monograph 55.)
Los Angeles, University of California, 2006, 4°, xvi-229 pp., tabl., figg., 29 pll. coul. ISBN 1-931745-27-7 (hbk) / 1-931745-26-9 (pbk). $65 (hbk) / $35 (pbk).

Joint expedition of the University of Delaware and Leiden University, 1994-2001. - Introduction. - 1. Rome's Eastern Trade. - 2. Natural Vegetation. - 3. Living in the Desert. - 4. Archaeobotanical Research. - 5. Peaches in the Desert. - 6. Interpretative Summary and Conclusion. - 7. Catalogue of Taxa. - Bibliography. Index to Scientific Plant Names. General Index.

C.R. par Arjan Zuiderhoek, BMCRev < http://ccat.sas.upenn.edu/bmcr/2006/2006-10-41.html >. - Véronique Dasen, MusHelv 64 (2007) p. 182. - Marijke van der Veen, JRA 20 (2007) pp. 631-634. - Alexis D'Hautcourt, The Kyoto Journal of Ancient History 8 (2008) pp. 79-86 [concerne aussi: David PEACOCK and Lucy BLUE (Edd.), assisted by Darren GLAZIER, The Ancient Red Sea Port of Adulis, Eritrea. Results of the Eritro-British Expedition 2004-5 (Oxford, 2007); - David PEACOCK and David WILLIAMS (Edd.), Food for the Gods. New Light on the Ancient Incense Trade (Oxford, 2007)].
